entry.title: Download
How To Use Zotero To Study Law at Deakin with Lexus Nexus
entry.content:
Adding Cases to Zotero

Law Reports Organised By Year (aka "Square Brackets")

Example: R v Monks [2011] VSC 626

Law Reports Organised by Volume

Example: R v Hughes (2002) 202 CLR 535

Law Report Containing A Number

Sykes v Cleary (No 2) (1992) 176 CLR 77

 

An Act Containing A Number

Conveyancing Act (No 6) 1919 (NSW)

 

***************************************************************************************************

Mining An Online Legal Database For Useful Information

1. Use the citation to find the case on an online legal database


2. Here is what you can easily add to the dabatase

Tagging Cases

1. Select the "Tags" tab

2. Click the "Add" button and a new entry field will appear...


3. Begin to enter a new tag and if it exists in the database, it'll appear after a couple of keystrokes...

4. Click with the mouse or use the DOWN direction key to select the existing tag.


Use Notes To Add Case Summaries and Other Information

1. Select the Notes tab


2. Click the "Add" button

3. Add a title and paste the digest

4. Click on the case name again and create another Note


5. Return to the case page on Lexus Nexus and click on the judgement

6. Skim read the judgement for a salient extract

7. Copy the paragraph of interest and paste it in a new Note as follows

Inserting A Citation in LibreOffice or Word (Not Pin-point):

Quick Format Citation

Classic Add/Edit Citation Window

Inserting A Pin-point Citation in LibreOffice or Word:

R v Hughes (2000) 202 CLR 535, 100.

R v Monks [2011] VSC 626, 200.

entry.title: Facebook Group for the Study Groups?
Statement Regarding the Deletion of the Presentation from the MLL214 Discussion Forum
entry.content:
The following statement is made in response to the recent action and post in the MLL214 Discussion Forum on Cloud Deakin by Marilyn McMahon,:
Subject:  Deletion of video regarding assignment    [Mark as read]
Marilyn McMahon, Tuesday, July 30, 2013 12:52 PM AEST
Dear all,
I have taken the extraordinary step of deleting a very good recording made by a student in MLL214 regarding the assignment. In essence, I have done so because the recording provides a very detailed discussion of key issues and provides explicit guidance in relation to the assignment. Consequently, the video provides a template which students can use to develop a standard response to the assignment. However, the assignment is meant to get students to do their own analysis and research - it is an individual assignment and, at the end of the day, must be your work.While discussion and exploration of issues is encouraged, the video provides far too much detailed advice and analysis of issues and,in my opinion, exceeds the permissible (and desirable) limits of discussion and exchange of ideas amongst student.
I completely accept that the video was made in good faith. But, for the reasons specified above, I have withdrawn the link. I trust that you will understand why this was appropriate.
Regards,
Marilyn 
All further videos discussing assignments in MLL214, MLL217, MLL323, MLL391, or any other subject at Deakin University or any other institution, during Trimester 2 or any other period of studies, will not be available for public viewing, and will exist for my personal reference only.

-- Alex Garber

entry.title: Readings and Study Sessions
entry.content:
Summary

As the over-arching purpose of the study sessions is to help DU members keep up with the demands of their subjects, there is no set format.  For myself, as the principal organiser of Deakin Unleashed Study Groups, my goal is to help the study sessions gather enough momentum so that they can run in my absence.
Also, I need to put aside enough time to stay abreast of all my subjects' readings.

With that in mind, the study sessions are intended to require nothing more than that you join us, whether you want to lead a discussion or simply hang around some friendly people while you catch up on your reading.

The following lists are suggested tasks, but are by no means required in each and every session:

Weekly Tasks

  • Review this week's contributions to the GDoc
  • Tidy up headings and sub-headings in the GDoc
  • Embed this week's snapshot of the GDoc in the Deakin Unleashed blog
  • Answer this week's tutorial questions
  • Answer this week's study guide questions
  • Answer the questions in the textbook for this week's topic
  • Add case and statute citations to Zotero
  • Add footnoted claims in the ODT document and generate a bibliography
  • Export the ODT document with footnotes and bibliography to DOCX
  • Upload this week's footnoted claims to Google Drive
  • Embed this week's footnoted claims in the Deakin Unleashed blog

Mid-term Assignment

  • Analyse and/or discuss the assignment question
  • Share and discuss research material for assignment
  • Discuss essay planning

End-of-term Examination

  • Analyse practice exam questions
  • Practice essay planning under test conditions
  • Practice essay writing under test conditions

entry.title: Alex's Study Schedule in Israel
Offline Editing in Google Docs
entry.content:
I am working on a video tutorial on using Google Docs offline.  In the meantime, here's what you need to know.

Main Points

  1. The #1 goal during lectures and between study sessions is to add as much content as possible.  Do not worry about what anyone else might think of your contributions -- anything you add is welcome and we will conduct regular reviews of the notes at least once a week to tidy up the contributions.
  2. Your contributions will NEVER be deleted permanently:
    1. Every Friday, we will take a snapshot of the notes and make them available as pre-review versions of the notes, so if something is removed during the review, you will always have the option of retrieving your contributions.
    2. You can download a copy of the notes at any time by going to File > Download as... and then downloading the document.  If you do not have offline editing enabled, this is strongly recommended. 

What NOT To Do

  • DO NOT delete headings
  • DO NOT delete sub-headings
  • DO NOT delete anyone else's contribution

What To Do

  • DO add notes
  • DO add bullet points
  • Do add enumerated points
  • Do add headings
  • Do add sub-headings

How To Enable Offline Editing on Your Computer

  1. Install Google Chrome
  2. Go to https://drive.google.com/#offline
  3. Download the Offline Editing app or browser extension
  4. Go back to https://drive.google.com/#offline
  5. Enable Offline editing

entry.title: Review of Week 01, Trimester 02, 2013
entry.content:
Hello everyone from MLL214, MLL217, MLL323, and MLL391,

Apologies for somewhat spamming you with Google Calendar invitations and updates; I believe that has all been taken care of.

Shout Outs for the Week


  • Steph Gaut for tremendous work on the MLL323 GDoc, those contributions are brilliant!
  • Martin Slampa for his contributions to the MLL214 GDoc, it was very exciting to see you typing away in the GDoc during the lecture.
  • Natalie NG for a number of insightful questions and alerting me to some technical bugs. 
  • Asmaa Hasanein for donating your incredible notes to the MLL214 cause.
I'd like to publish these weekly review emails to the blog as well, so please let me know if you prefer not to be mentioned by name on the blog.

VERY IMPORTANT

Natalie NG alerted me to a bug in GCal's invitations that states the time of the event in GMT (London, UK), rather than AEST (Melbourne).  This has something to do with the fact that I have both timezones displayed on my calendar.  If you accept the invitation, it SHOULD show up at the actual, Melbourne time, but let me know ASAP if it shows up at a strange times.

Please refer to the embedded calendar in the About page:
http://deakinunleashed.blogspot.com.au/p/about.html

Communicating with Study Group Members

I'd like to make this blog my sole medium of communication with you, and to this end, I have included a very easy subscribe-by-email gadget:



Here is a video tutorial that I recorded demonstrating how this subscription-by-email gadget works:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q848BPjhxBI&feature=youtu.be

You can also subscribe via RSS using this feed url:
http://deakinunleashed.blogspot.com/feeds/posts/default

entry.title: Food for the Study Groups
entry.content:
One easy and rather important way to contribute to your DUSG is to bring snacks to share.  Although chocolates and lollies will always be welcome, it's probably better to get into the habit of bringing healthier snacks too.

Healthy Snack Ideas

  • Carrots or celery
  • Dips
  • Fruit or dried fruit
  • Baked items
  • Nuts
Feel free to mention any other healthy snack ideas in the comments and I'll add them to the list.

entry.title: Does the common law objective test for apprehension of an imminent threat still apply to murder and defensive homicide?
entry.content: According to the Crimes Act 1958 (Vic), ss 9AC and 9AD, the test for self-defence as a complete defence to murder is a two-leg test.  If we include the traditional common law requirement that D have believed on reasonable grounds that the threat that give rise to the conduct that constitutes murder was imminent, it seems to be a three-leg test.

entry.title: Questions To Ask Prospective Employers
entry.content:
1. How much money does a law firm have to invest in its entry-level graduates before they become profitable to employ? 
    1. How much does an entry-level graduate lawyer earn in the first year?
    2. How much training or professional development does he require before he can be assigned money-making or money-saving tasks?
    3. How many weeks/months/years does it take before a graduate is assigned money-making or money-saving tasks?
    4. What net-expense tasks are assigned to him in this initial phase?
    5. Which attributes are correlated with a speedy transition from net-expense employment to profitable employment?
  2. Who can tell me more about this?
  3. Why do you not have this kind of information to hand?

entry.title: How To Correct The Wonky Capitalisation in the 'Reporter' Field (LibreOffice or Word Plugin for Zotero)
entry.content:
If you enter citation (I've only seen it with a square bracket citation so far) and it looks wonky, try this:

Go to Set Document Preferences:

 
And then make sure to untick "Automatically abbreviate journal titles":


 

It worked for me on Linux using LibreOffice, but it should work on other systems too.

entry.title: About DUSG
entry.content:
Information for Members of the Deakin Unleashed Study Groups

About Me

This term (T2, 2013 at Deakin), I am studying the following subjects:
  • MLL214: Criminal Law
  • MLL217: Misleading Conduct and Economic Torts
  • MLL323: Constitutional Law
  • MLL391: Civil Procedure and Alternative Dispute Resolution

Shared Notes on Google Documents

I keep my lecture notes in the following Google Documents, which are currently publicly available.  I will make them completely private (i.e. accessible only to group members) at the end of Week 2, Trimester 2, 2013.  Visitors cannot edit the document, but you are invited to use the comments section to introduce yourselves.
  • Criminal Law Google Document
  • Misleading Conduct and Economic Torts Google Documents
  • Constitutional Law Google Document
  • Civil Procedure and Alternative Dispute Resolution Google Document

The Main Goals of Sharing Notes

  1. To share the load of writing summary notes.
  2. To have a shared resource for discussing the subject matter.
  3. To have a comprehensive reference document for practice questions.
  4. To have a comprehensive reference document to take into the examination at the end of the term.
I tried this approach last term in two of my subjects and it worked very well for both me and my study partner because we both contributed heavily to the document and ensured that the final document contained all the information we needed for the exam.

Zotero and LibreOffice

I also use Zotero as my citation database and I strongly encourage you to download and install it on your computer.  I am more than happy to teach you how to use it.  Zotero is completely free and open source.

Download Zotero from here

Zotero automates citations by means of a plug-in for either Microsoft Word or LibreOffice Writer, which is a free and open source alternative to Microsoft Word.  You can open MS Office documents in LibreOffice and save documents in a Microsoft Word format (DOC or DOCX) in LibreOffice too.  Owing to a certain technical limitation, I cannot easily share my compilations of footnotes with users of Microsoft Office, so I strongly recommend that you download and install LibreOffice.  It will not affect the performance of Microsoft Office on your computer, and as a long-time user of LibreOffice, which I have used for all my assignments here at Deakin, I can assure you that it is just as good.

Download LibreOffice from here

Technical Support

I have been trading as Clockwork PC since 2010, providing technical support on Windows, MacOSX, Linux, Android, iOS.  I can help you with most Cloud Deakin queries, Zotero, bCisive, LibreOffice, a bit of Microsoft Office, and general software and hardware issues.

Technical Tips on YouTube

I have started a YouTube channel where I will record brief instructional videos on how to study effectually and also longer video presentations about the material.  Check out my channel, TabulaLex on YouTube:

Deakin Law Study Group Sessions

At this early stage of the trimester, I am still working out the most convenient times, but the time blocks marked "Available Study Session" can be set aside for any of the four subjects -- MLL214, MLL217, MLL323, MLL391.  I'd prefer to dedicate each time slot to the same subject every week, but am happy to discuss changes as we go along.  Please email or call me as soon as possible with a list of your preferred time slots, and let me know if you have any suggestions.


Fair Work Policy

I am confident that we'll find each other to be good study partners this term, and if you know someone from class that you think would work well with Google Docs and Zotero feel free to tell him/her to get in touch with me, in person, by phone, or by email.

Although I have already invested considerable time and effort in setting up these groups, and am happy to continue managing and coordinating the study groups, everyone who is part of a study group shall be expected to contribute in some way -- adding content, participating in discussions, asking questions, finding resources, etc.  If it becomes clear that you are free-riding on this group, I will give you chance to make a copy of the notes and then revoke your access to the Google Document/s and any other shared resources shortly thereafter.

Tasks To Be Completed for Each Subject

Weekly Tasks

  1. Create headings and sub-headings in the GDoc
  2. Under the headings and sub-headings, add lecture notes, summary notes, etc
  3. Add case and statute citations to Zotero
  4. Add footnoted claims in the ODT document and generate a bibliography
  5. Export the ODT document with footnotes and bibliography to DOCX
  6. Answer this week's tutorial questions
  7. Answer this week's study guide questions
  8. Answer the questions in the textbook for this week's topic
  9. Analyse the assignment question

Mid-trimester Assignment

  1. Analyse the assignment question
  2. Identify research topics
  3. Research
  4. Add case citations to Zotero
  5. Add statute citations to Zotero
  6. Add article citations to Zotero

End-of-trimester Examination

  1. Analysing past exam questions
  2. Research and reading
  3. Essay planning
  4. Writing practice essays under exam conditions
